"A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed."

The SCOTUS decision in Heller:

The Supreme Court held that:

(1) The Second Amendment protects an individual right to possess a firearm unconnected with service in a militia, and to use that arm for traditionally lawful purposes, such as self-defense within the home.
(a) The Amendment’s prefatory clause announces a purpose, but does not limit or expand the scope of the second part, the operative clause. The operative clause’s text and history demonstrate that it connotes an individual right to keep and bear arms.
(b) The prefatory clause comports with the Court’s interpretation of the operative clause. The “militia” comprised all males physically capable of acting in concert for the common defense. The Antifederalists feared that the Federal Government would disarm the people in order to disable this citizens’ militia, enabling a politicized standing army or a select militia to rule. The response was to deny Congress power to abridge the ancient right of individuals to keep and bear arms, so that the ideal of a citizens’ militia would be preserved.
Law enforcement is charged only with enforcing the letter - not necessarily the intent - of the law.   So why pass a law that can't be easily enforced?

Oy, about Ezra.

I think someone has to come out and directly say it, even if it is just little old me.

Ezra, is under great pressure not to look too un-"Balanced", or too un-"Centrist". He can't just always say what he thinks is true in a very, very clear, direct, precise, un-vague way, like Paul Krugman does, and like people who don't have much to lose from it, like myself, do.

What you are calling "the substance of the debate" is completely irrelevant here. The question at hand is whether it is ethical for a teacher to force their students to express a *public* political opinion on an issue. Even if the issue were "save the cute puppies", it should be the student's right to refuse to participate in political activity to save cute puppies.

As an aside, regardless of whether the science of climate change is "settled" or not, it is indisputable that the politics of how we'll deal with it is not settled at all.

He was mesmerizing.

Few people belonged on the silver screen as much as Peter O'Toole. His presence dominated any scene. He had his brilliant moments on stage as well where he was no less mesmerizing. His knowledge of Shakespeare and the English language was impeccable. He could rightly be called a scholar were he ever to accept that title. He elevated the arts to a higher level. That he did not receive an Academy Award for one of his films is more a reflection on the Academy than on him. That he received an honorary Academy Award late in life must partly have been because the Academy learned the error of its ways. He himself rejected knighthood on principle. His heart was Irish. His likes will not be seen again.

Burton was not considered for the part.  Sam Spiegal wanted Marlon Brando and thank god Brando turned it down (said he preferred to film Mutiny in Tahiti than Lawrence in the desert).   Spiegal had signed Alain Delon for Ali but when he couldn't wear contact lenses to make his eyes brown (thank god), Spiegal went looking for an English speaking Arab and found Omar.  Brando and Delon would have been a masterpiece of miscasting.  The in-depth story of the making of Lawrence has been written - book should be available on Amazon -- The Making of Lawrence of Arabia. (The authors also note that Lean wanted O'Toole to do Zhivago and when he demurred because he didn't see himself in the role, it want to Omar.  Lean was so angry he didn't speak to him for years.)
"Restore?"  Why not "confirm?"
I agree completely - he was stunning in The Ruling Class.
Our loving thoughts and prayers to his family/friends he was a stellar performer, his best performance ' The Ruling Class ' by far!
Yes, he should have won the Oscar for Lawrence of Arabia but even more so for The Lion in Winter; he was Kate's match!
He should have, also,  won the Oscar for The Lion in Winter.
After all of these years, Lawrence of Arabia is still the best.  He should have won the Oscar.

From the lilt in his voice from a line like "Michael George Hartly, you're a philosopher" in Lawrence of Arabia
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQ33gYBFDnE (11:01) to his deep recitation of Shakespeare's "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day" in Venus
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iRIxb6_ELNg (1:04)
and so much in between, very few had the subtle command of language and voice like Mr. O'Toole. It flowed like music, was so melifluous, and mesmerized in addition to the rest of his physicality in his eyes, gestures, and whole being. The body is the actor's instrument, and Peter O'Toole was the master player bringing vim, vitality, verve, zeal, zing, and intensity that could elicit our own subtle emotions to the surface, those usually buried beneath the everyday simple "no drama" emotion masks that we apply to live in the modern world and be consumer/producers. He along with his other compatriots like Burton, showed us the possibility in how humans can communicate with other humans expressing such a range of emotions, possibilities that seem to recede in our email/text world.
O'Toole is one of the few actors who could have read a phone book onstage and made it sound amazing!  He will be sorely missed!
The role he passed on was Zhivago - astutely recognizing that it was not right for him. Sharif was hoping for a small role - Strelnikov perhaps - and was stunned when he was offered the lead.
RIP Peter O'Toole.

You look at economic cruelty as being intentional. In reality, most Americans vote against their own self-interests because they simply don't understand the inexorable working out of impersonal economic forces.

One of those forces is population growth, which ultimately causes shortages in the essentials of living for the poor.

Democrats contribute to population growth by supporting illegal immigration and providing welfare benefits that encourage larger families among the poor (even as most in the middle class find it difficult to afford families).

Democracy comes with a responsibility---to become informed. Yet newspapers like the NY Times make it impossible for the average person to be well-informed because certain ideas are censored.

When is the last time you saw an article on the impact of population growth on living standards in the NY Times.

The information is available on the web, and it is glaringly obvious to those who think for themselves that population growth of .9% per year (as in the US) is unsustainable in the long run.

Yet our media censor expression of this idea by calling the discussion of population growth "racist."

Without even being afforded the opportunity to fully discuss the impact of population growth in public forums, the American economy descends toward a Malthusian end state.

And Americans remain clueless about the reasons for their declining living standards.

You fail to see that government is an incompetent, wasteful blunt instrument.
Freedom always works better and does not destroy people's self esteem in the process.

There you go again, Bret, arguing that those ignorant poor people keep having babies because it gets them more welfare benefits. And then your never-ending cop-out: "....most Americans vote against their own self-interests because they simply don't understand the inexorable working out of impersonal economic forces." To say that something is "inexorable" is to say that it's inevitable, something that destroys any hope of democracy working. If people's votes meant nothing, why would they bother? Voting people into office who aren't limited by ideas of inevitability is what has democracy work.

The sad reality of the United States, when compared with all other advanced "democracies", can only be explained by culture. The best example of this is the national attitude to providing basic health care to all citizens, literally "taking care of each other."

The culture of the United States is hateful and mean. Nothing else could explain the open hostility to the simple idea of all citzens being ENTITLED to necessary health care. The average American seems to see life as a vicious competition, with the losers potentially paying with their lives.

The ultimate demonstration of this culture of mutual hatred is the fact that the vast majority in a democracy are incapable of using their votes to secure their own well-being. It is beyond belief that the American middle class is so caught up in their "aspiration" that they allow tens of millions to work for poverty wages.

Americans would rather tread on each other than offer a helping hand.

Higher taxes are the solution. Redistribution of the excessive profits collected by the rich through the government would go along way toward spreading the benefits of our economy more widely. Trickle down economics has been revealed as the lie it always was.

The constitution guarantees every citizen one vote, and guarantees every citizen the freedom to use whatever resources that citizen commands - be it money, education, celebrity, shoe-leather, control of a printing press or a computer, articulateness, whatever - to persuade the voters to vote one way or another.  It most emphatically does not guarantee everyone an "equal voice" in political matters.  The only states where every citizen has an "equal voice" in picking leaders and choosing policies are those where no one (except for Dear Leader) has any voice.

"The party -of -the one- percent is able to get more than one percent of the vote?" aided and abetted by a mass of people voting contrary to their own socioeconomic interests.

Because far too many of them dream and believe that they have a realistic chance of one day very soon of waking up as the next Rockefeller.

Because far too many of them believe that most people are poor because they are lazy, ignorant and immoral.

Because far too many of them believe that most people are rich because of their hard work, wisdom/brilliance and morality.

If we are not our brother's keepers and we do not hear the bell tolling for ourselves amidst another's misfortune then we are doomed to follow this cycle to even more outrageous and depraved depths.

We are on the brink of a socioeconomic political nuclear melt down. It is not income inequality per se that is the real problem. It is the increasing rigid permanence and persistence of that status that is running amok. Social immobility due to a rigged unfair systemic structure is a threat that should not and can be tolerated. It mocks our values. And it hurts our interests.

@Douglas
You say the Constitution "guarantees every citizen the freedom to use whatever resources that citizen commands - be it money, education, celebrity, shoe-leather, control of a printing press or a computer, articulateness, whatever - to persuade the voters to vote one way or another." Where does it say so? Does the Constitution also guarantee every citizen the right to be swindled? To be prevented from voting? To be gerrymandered out of any semblance of democratic elections? Is the choice between the jungle and totalitarianism?

In our market economy each of us "votes" for the success of products (and services) in a weighted fashion -- each person has as many "votes" as we have dollars that we are able and willing to devote to each product.

In democracy, each of us is theoretically supposed to have an equal individual vote, un-weighted by our individual strength in dollar-terms. Voting should take place in an environment that neutralizes the influences of money, so that, at least in that one important area of society, power does not flow disproportionately to those who already have most of the economic power. Perhaps that would tend to correct the prevalence of folks being persuaded to vote against their own best interests by barrages of malicious advertising.

How is it that the party-of-the-one-percent is able to get more than one percent of the vote?

Well, yes - every class assignment "requiring" a book to be read "compels" a pupil to read the book. It even makes sense that a teacher might require a student to argue one or both sides of a book, be it philosophical or scientific. It does not make sense that a teacher would require a student to publicly profess the ideas in a book or scientific concept which may not be his/her own.

'A teacher can compel a student to read a book, but he can’t compel the pupil to philosophically internalize the themes of that book in order to pass the class.'

This 'ethical' position seems to me to be a not so subtle reproach for having students study and do something positive regarding climate change. The idea that a student is 'compelled' to read a book is ludicrous, unless you describe every class assignment which requires that a book be read as being compelled.
